text:
We are on a path to give everyone
a personal AI assistant

that's going to feel like 
you have a human assistant.
It’s going to care about you.

It's going to help you get things done
in a thoughtful, safe, and practical way.
Ninja AI: “I'm all about making your life easier.”

We are on a precipice of actually
bringing that into reality.

We're about to launch the very first 
version of it in a public beta.
This is a technology that's for everybody.
Ninja AI is able to interact with the real world
with a certain goal, to get a particular task done for you.

Let's say I'm a gamer and I'm looking 
to buy the best TV for gaming.

So you’d start to present this question, 
“What is the best TV to buy

that's under 65 inches,
which is less than $3,000
that performs really well for gaming.”
It can do that homework quickly

and come back with a meaningful answer
while you're focusing on something else.
In essence, it becomes a force multiplier for you.
What we are building can help people
to solve and tackle hard problems that wasn't feasible to solve.
Out of the gate, we have five agents.

The first one, it's our Intent Analyzer,
and it’s job is to figure out
which agent to activate.

We have a Scheduler agent, a Researcher
agent, a Coder agent, and an Advisor agent.

We break it down into smaller
AI agents that are specialized,

you train them to have genuine
new thoughts in a narrow lane,

and then you have a conductor
or orchestrator on top.

You're basically using all the skills
in conjunction together

to build a much more intelligent and 
smooth experience for the user.

These agents should learn 
the preferences of each person

and have a great memory
of what a human wants them to do.
It used to be that

you would have to be part
of a very large company

with lots of resources
to be able to do this.
But now, two things have changed.
First, having access to very powerful

open source models that are responsibly
made and are very capable.
But the second thing,

perhaps even more important,
is having access to machines to compute;

AI chips that can actually handle
workloads of AI, which are different.

For the types of things that 
we're trying to do, a lot of times

you need a lot of machines and 
you need them in bursting modes.

When you do training, you want to throw
a lot of chips at it and you're done.
This has been very, very expensive.

Lowering the barrier 
to perform experimentation,
I think, for any scientist, is key.
We established a deep partnership with
AWS, in particular the Annapurna Labs, and together,

we were able to build and run our models 
on their purposeful built chips,
in particular, Trainium and Inferentia.

And the whole thing was trained
on Trainium and it runs on Inferentia.

AWS’s chips are especially good
for reinforcement learning,

to a point that we moved all of our
AI infrastructure to these chips,

which makes it super exciting,
but also viable and affordable.

And it's been a game changer for us 
as an early-stage startup.

The immense support that we get from AWS
has been paramount to pulling this off.
As this evolves, we hope to see the proliferation

and democratization of personal
AI that can be leveraged by everyone.

When I’m going to look back, I want to say we
did something that left a positive note.

Having AI agents that pass the Alan
Turing test, that's my hope.

Ninja AI: “I'm here to help you
with whatever you need.
“What's on your mind today?”
And we are getting very close.
We're touching the future.

It's a super exciting time to be 
doing a generative AI company.
